title: Aber Falls Circular Walk Route

images.title: Chris Shaw / Aber Falls, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Aber Falls. The falls are formed as the Afon Goch plunges about 120 feet (37 m) over a sill of ancient igneous rock in the foothills of the Carneddau mountain range.

images.title: Ian Greig / The river in spate above Aber Falls, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The river in spate above Aber Falls

images.title: Eric Jones / View across to the foot of Rhaeadr-Fawr/Aber Falls, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View across to the foot of Rhaeadr-Fawr

images.title: John Rostron / Rhaeadr-fawr or Aber Falls, from below, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View of the falls from below. People like to bathe in the plung pool though care must be taken on the slippery rocks.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Bronze age burial cairn, near the Aber Falls
images.caption: Bronze age burial cairn, near the falls. Aber Falls has been a site of human settlement since prehistoric times, with archaeological discoveries revealing stone circles and Roman remains nearby. This rather unprepossessing piece of rough ground and stones in the middle of a patch of cleared forest is a bronze age burial cairn (one of various such remains in the area). Moel Wnion can be seen in the background, together with three lines of pylons which carry transmission lines over the hills rather than along the very restricted coastal route. Several standing stones and cairns can also be seen nearby.

images.title: John Rostron / Beginning of the trail from the car park to Aber Falls
images.caption: Beginning of the trail from the car park to the falls. It had rained heavily overnight, hence the puddles on the path, and the 'steaming' from the trees. The nearby Aber Falls Distillery produces gin and whisky, drawing water from the same streams that feed the falls.

images.title: Martin Wilson / Aber Falls & valley
images.caption: Wider view of the valley of Afon Rheadr Fawr with peaks of Foel Ganol in the far distance.

images.title: Ian Greig / Aber Falls from Marian Rhaeadr-fawr scree slope
images.caption: The falls viewd from the Marian Rhaeadr-fawr scree slope. In winter, the falls can freeze, creating dramatic ice formations popular with photographers and hikers. There's a lesser-known second waterfall nearby, Rhaeadr Bach, which can be reached via an extension of the walking trail.

description: Follow a splendid walking trail up to the beautiful Aber Falls on this circular walk in the Snowdonia National Park. Aber Falls (Rhaeadr Fawr in Welsh) is located near the village of Abergwyngregyn in Gwynedd. The walk starts at the car park at Bont Newydd and follows the North Wales Path along the Afon Rhaeadr Fawr to the 120 ft high falls. You'll pass through the stunning scenery of the Coedydd National Nature Reserve with its wonderful woodland and mountain scenery. There's also a variety of wildlife to look out for including treecreepers, sparrowhawks, woodpeckers, tree pipits, skylarks and buzzards. If you're lucky you may spot polecats, stoat and lizards too. The walk involves a moderate climb but you're rewarded with magnificent views of the surrounding countryside and mountains from the high points. For a shorter route to the falls see our Aber Falls Easy Walk .
